title-group.article-title: Malposition of a Central Venous Catheter Into the Right Internal Mammary Vein: Review of Complications of Catheter Misplacement

article-meta.aff: 1CAMC Vascular Center of Excellence, CAMC Heart and Vascular Center, Charleston, WV, USA

author-notes.corresp: Patrick A. Stone, CAMC Vascular Center of Excellence, Fourth floor, CAMC Heart and Vascular Center, 3200 MacCorkle Ave. SE, Charleston, WV 25304, USA Email: pstone0627@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Central venous catheters are commonly utilized to gain vascular access for varied clinical indications. Successful catheter placement requires not only technical expertise but also awareness of the potential complications. In this article, we report a malposition of a central venous catheter in a hemodialysis patient. We review the complications of this catheter misplacement, as well as complications resulting from other central venous catheter malpositions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 26 million people, progressing to end-stage renal disease each year. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates the prevalence of hemodialysis (HD)-dependent person at 0.4% of the US population.1 Current Kidney Dialysis Outcome Quality Initiative (KDOQI) guidelines recommend patient referral to a vascular surgeon for education about vascular access for HD. Once a patient has been diagnosed with CKD stage 4 (estimated glomerular filtration rate < 30 mL/min/1.73m2), the KDOQI recommends early creation of arteriovenous (AV) access prior to complete kidney failure. The preferred access is a creation of an AV fistula in the nondominant forearm, with other access site considered in a stepwise manner (ie, nondominant upper arm, to dominant forearm, to dominant upper arm, etc).2

Despite efforts to create suitable vascular access in renal patients with early surgical creation of an AV fistula, tunneled HD catheters remain an important adjunct for temporal and medium-term access for HD. All central venous catheters have many known complications. The most common complications arising from insertion of the catheter include pneumothorax, arterial puncture, local infection, thrombosis, hematomas, dysrhythmia, and thrombosis.3–5 Mechanical complications of tunneled catheters include kinking and occlusion of the catheter. A rare complication that was recently encountered at our institution was the inadvertent insertion of catheter into the right internal mammary vein, despite the use of fluoroscopy for confirmation of positioning. This case report will review the presentation of the complication and discuss this unusual catheter placement as compared with the current literature.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 49-year-old woman was admitted to Charleston Area Medical Center for evaluation of a fever (103°F) and arm cellulitis over previously placed AV access. With further evaluation, it was noted that the patient’s left brachioaxillary AV graft, which was used for dialysis, was infected. The patient’s AV graft was subsequently removed and there was placement of a tunneled HD catheter via a right internal jugular vein ultrasound-guided access.

Procedural details included—the right internal jugular vein was accessed with ultrasound guidance via a lateral supraclavicular approach. After the access was achieved, a 0.035 guide wire was advanced without any difficulty into what appeared to be the superior vena cava (SVC). A counter incision was made over the chest wall. A 14.5F × 19 cm cuff to tip dialysis catheter (Tal Palindrome, Covidien, Dublin, Ireland) was tunneled into the jugular vein entrance site. Sequential increasing venous dilation was performed with fluoroscopic assistance then advancement of a peel away sheath into the venous system. The catheter was then advanced, with tip of the catheter at the SVC-right atrial junction and sheath subsequently removed.

caption.p: Chest x-ray: Anterior-posterior demonstrating what appears to be good positon of catheter in the superior vena-cava.
Computed Tomography (Axial image): Catheter posterior and to the right of the sternum.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This case report demonstrates the rare malposition of a central venous catheter into the right mammary vein. Although many known mechanical complications of catheters are known, kinking, malposition in the ipsilateral jugular, or innominante vein placement. Few cases reported on malposition in the internal mammary vein.4,5

Anatomically, unlike the internal mammary artery which arises from the subclavian artery, the internal mammary vein originates from the innominate vein. This vein travels adjacent to the same named artery on the posterior aspect of the anterior chest wall. From a right internal jugular approach, this anterior branch overlies the SVC and standard PA chest radiographs appear to have placement within the SVC. However, lateral imaging is needed to confirm this placement.

In this specific case, there was concern of catheter malposition secondary to severe pain in the chest open aspiration and flushing the catheter. Unaware of this potential malposition, a CT examination of the chest was performed. The axial imaging demonstrates the catheter just posterior to the sternum. A lateral chest film could have revealed this anterior catheter placement but still would have not clearly shown whether the catheter was in the venous system.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Catheter malposition following dialysis catheter placement is not unusual; however, placement within central venous branches is uncommonly reported. Understanding and review of the central venous branches can help physicians appreciate successful catheter placement.
